Constructor Detail

AppletBase

public AppletBase()
Method Detail

setBackgroundImage

public void setBackgroundImage(java.lang.String filename)
Changes the background of the simulation to the background image specified by the filename. Once the file is loaded, the simulation window is resized to fit the new background image. Files must be jpg or gif images. If the file is not found, the simulation will exit.

Parameters:
filename - The name of the file to use. If it is not in the current directory, the filename should be a fully qualified name.

setBackgroundTile

public void setBackgroundTile(java.lang.String filename)
Sets the background to the specified image, and tiles the image so that it fills the current simulation window. Using this method ensures that the image fills the simulation, as opposed to setBackgroundImage which ensures the simulation fits the image. If the file cannot be found, the simulation will exit.

Parameters:
filename - The name of the file to use.

Empty

getHITSensor

public int getHITSensor()
Gets the value from the HIT sensor, if one is connected. The readings returned represent the side of the sensor that is receiving the most light, with negative values to the left and positive values to the right.

Returns:
Empty

getInt

public int getInt(java.lang.String prompt)
Undocumented

Parameters:
prompt - Empty
Returns:
Empty

getLightSensor

public int getLightSensor()
Gets the reading from the light sensor. The value returned is roughly equivalent to the percentage of light that the sensor detects. The values are determined by the light sensor, but usually fall between 29 and 50. If the simulation is running in idealistic mode, the values will correspond to color constants from eecs.jago.element.ReflectiveColors.

Returns:
The current reading.

setPower

public void setPower(int power)
Sets the power of the robot to the specified level.

Parameters:
power - The power setting, between 1 and 10.

setRealismLevel

public void setRealismLevel(int level)
This method is included to be consistent with the Realism interface. The preferred method in the EECS wrapper is to use the setIdealisticSim and setRealisticSim methods.

Specified by:
setRealismLevel in interface jago.Realism
Parameters:
level - REALISTIC or IDEALISTIC

createRobot

public void createRobot(int x,
                        int y,
                        int angle)
Adds a robot to the simulation at the specified coordinates and initial heading. This method creates a LegoRobot, which by default has a standard Lego light sensor (see eecs.jago.element.RobotSensors#LIGHT) and a standard bumper (see eecs.jago.element.RobotSensors#TOUCH). The light sensor is connected to the RCX input 1, (RCX_1) and the touch sensor is connected to the RCX input 2 (RCX_2).

Parameters:
x - The x coordinate, with the upper left being 0.
y - The y coordinate, with the upper left being 0.
angle - The initial direction; straight up is a heading of 0.

destroyRobot

public void destroyRobot()
Removes the robot from the simulation

drawTrails

public void drawTrails(boolean on)
Undocumented

Parameters:
on - Empty

goBackward

public void goBackward()
Causes the robot to begin driving backward. The robot will continue to move until another command is issued.

goBackward

public void goBackward(int ms)
Causes the robot to move backward for the specified amount of time. The amount of time is actually measured in simulation time, which may not mirror real time.

Parameters:
ms - The amount of time that the robot should move.

goForward

public void goForward()
Causes the robot's motors to turn on in the forward direction. Once this command is issued, the robot will continue to move forward until another command is issued.

goForward

public void goForward(int ms)
Causes the robot to move forward for the specified amount of time. The time specified is relative to the amount of time that passes in the simulation, which may not exactly mirror real-world time.

Parameters:
ms - How long the robot should drive forward, in milliseconds

runFixedRealisticSim

public void runFixedRealisticSim()
Causes the simulation to run in a mode that isn't idealistic, but will be consistent between runs. For robots, this means that the robot might drift (not drive straight), but it will drift exactly the same every time the program is run in this mode.

runIdealisticSim

public void runIdealisticSim()
Causes the simulation to run in a mode that represents the ideal function of all elements. Although the exact operation is determined by the individual elements, this generally means that the behavior is one that would allow the most accurate use of the component.

runRealisticSim

public void runRealisticSim()
Causes the simulation to run in a mode that more accurately represents how the elements would act in the real world. The implementation determines what impact this command actually has, but in general it will cause some level of stochiastic behavior.
